message_1: Suppose you have a message of 20 characters that you want to hash using SHA-256. What will be the length of the resulting hash value in hexadecimal notation?
message_2:
SHA-256 always produces a fixed-length hash value of 256 bits. To represent this hash value in hexadecimal notation, we need to convert the number of bits to hexadecimal characters. Since each hexadecimal character represents 4 bits (as there are 16 possible values: 0-9 and A-F), we can calculate the length of the resulting hash value in hexadecimal notation as follows:

Length in hexadecimal = (Length in bits) / 4
Length in hexadecimal = 256 / 4
Length in hexadecimal = 64

So, the length of the resulting hash value in hexadecimal notation will be 64 characters.
